We can find nothing on record here to show what the position was before 1934, though R.A.F. planes had certainly visited Muscat for three or four years before that date, but it is clear that from the 25th October 1934 to the 24th October 1938,while the Civil Air Agreement was in force, R.A.F. fuel was explicitly exempted from customs duty under Article 15. It would appear unlikely, however, that this somewhat incidental reference to the exemption of R.A.F. fuel in the Civil $ir Agreement can have been the only basis for immunity from customs duty, and one would judge from the fact that the Sultan did not apparently impose customs duty on R.A.F.fuel from the date of the expiry of the Civil Air Agreement that he regarded his verbal promise of exemption, reported in para.3 of your express letter of the 2nd September 1934, No.842 S, as holding good quite independently of the Civil Air Agreement. In any case the interval/interval between the expiry of the Civil Air Agreement and the coming into force of the new treaty from the 11th February 1939 is a matter of a few months only and from that date the Sultan is debarred under Art. 5 (4) (c) from imposing customs duties on r.A.F. fuel. 2. It appears therefore that it is the case that at any rate from October 1934 R.A.F. fuel has always been exempted from customs duty and though it is true that there is no treaty or other provision which would enable objection to be taken in principle to the levy of municipal taxes on R.A.F. stores, the fact that the present tax is levied 'on each package which is liable to customs duty' would appear to afford adequate justification for objecting to the imposition of the tax on R.A.F.stores. Sir, I have the honour to state that with a view to improving the sanitation of the towns of Muscat and Mattrah which are at present in a very insanitary condition*, His Highness the Sultan of Muscat wishes to form a Municipality to undertake this very necessary duty. When 1 was last in Muscat His Highness represented to me firstly, that under Article 13 of the Muscat Commercial V(- Treaty of 1891 he possessed no jurisdiction to compel British residents, of whom there are a large number at Muscat - practically all British Indian, to conform to such local Municipal rules which may be framed, and secondly, that except under a general agreement of the nature described in Article 19 of the same Treaty he could not recover from British residents the taxes required to be imposed for the financing of the Municipality and that in these circumstances he could scarcely tax his own subjects. 2. His Highness referred to the King’s Regulation of 1911 (see paragraph 3 below). I explained tactfully that it had never been put into force, and that it was in ray opinion unsuitable. 3. Under King’s Regulation No.2 of 1911, framed under the Muscat Order in Council, 1867, British subjects and British protected persons residing at Muscat and Mattrah are requiredrequired to conform to the rules issued by the Muscat Government to its own subjects for the proper conservancy and sanitation of the towns. This Regulation, however, is, I consider unsuitable in that (a) it is too loosely worded and does not provide for the prior approval of the Political Resident to any measures which may be applied by the Muscat Government, a precaution which I consider essential and (b) it does not provide for the payment of municipal taxes by British subjects, who in my opinion, should not escape such taxation. 4. This, while permitting the application of local rules and taxes to British subjects, enables the Political Resident, who would normally act through the Political Agent, to prevent the application of any oojectionable measures to British subjects. ■Articl e This is necessary since the houses of owners, absent in India, may be in a condition dangerous to the public and may need demolition. mods.abstract: Correspondence and minute papers relating to the drafting and issue of 'The Muscat (Municipal) Regulations 1935'. The papers cover the search for consensus between the India Office, Foreign Office, and Political Residency over the text of the new regulations.Further correspondence (folios 3-28) from the Air Ministry and Air Officer Commanding in Iraq deals with the question of whether the Royal Air Force should be exempt from paying municipal tax on fuel.
